review.title: Morpho-syntactic Lexicon Generation Using Graph-based Semi-supervised Learning
review.abstract: Morpho-syntactic lexicons provide information about the morphological and syntactic roles of words in a language. Such lexicons are not available for all languages and even when available, their coverage can be limited. We present a graph-based semi-supervised learning method that uses the morphological, syntactic and semantic relations between words to automatically construct wide coverage lexicons from small seed sets. Our method is language-independent, and we show that we can expand a 1000 word seed lexicon to more than 100 times its size with high quality for 11 languages. In addition, the automatically created lexicons provide features that improve performance in two downstream tasks: morphological tagging and dependency parsing.

sections.heading: 4.2 Manually Curated Lexicons
sections.text: We have now shown that it is possible to automatically construct large lexicographs from smaller seed lexicographs. However, the seed lexicographs used in Section 4.1 have been artificially constructed from the aggregation of attributes of word types above the tree bank. Therefore, it can be argued that these constructed lexicographs may not be complete, i.e. the lexicographical lexicographs may not have all possible attributes for a particular word. On the other hand, manually curated lexicographs are not available for many languages, which prevents proper evaluation. To test the usefulness of our approach to manually curated lexicographs, we examine publicly available lexicographs for Finnish (Pirinen, 2011), Czech (Hajic and Hladka, 1998b) and Hungarian (Tro, et al., 2006). We eliminate numbers and punctuation in all lexicographics. For each of these languages, we select 10,000 words for training and the rest of the word types for the evaluation criterion.

sections.heading: 5 Extrinsic Evaluation
sections.text: We now show that the automatically generated dictionaries offer informative functions that are useful for two downstream NLP tasks: morphological marking (§ 5.1) and syntactic dependency analysis (§ 5.2).

sections.heading: 5.1 Morphological Tagging
sections.text: Morphological marking is the task of assigning a morphological reading to a character in context. Morphological reading consists of features such as part of speech, case, gender, person, tense, etc. (Oflazer and Kuruo � z, 1994; Hajic and Hladka, 1998a) The model we use is a standard atomic sequence classifier that classifies the morphological bundle for each word independently of the others (except for the features derived from these words). Specifically, we use a linear SVM model classifier with hand-controlled features, similar to commonly used analyzers such as SVMTagger (Ma, rquez and Gime, nez, 2004) and MateTagger (Bohnet and Nivre, 2012). Our taggers are trained in a language-independent manner (Hajic, 2000; Smith et al, 2005; Mu, et al, 2013).

sections.heading: 5.2 Dependency Parsing
sections.text: We train the dependency savers for the same 11 universal dependence tree banks that contain the morphological layer (Agic ́ et al., 2015). We re-use the supplied breakdown of the dependence tree bank into train, development and test to develop the models. Our analysis model is the transition-based analysis system of Zhang and Nivre (2011) with identical characteristics and a bar of size 8. We expand the characteristics of Zhang and Nivre (2011) in two ways: by using the context-independent morphological attributes present in the various lexicographs; and by using the corresponding morphological markers from § 5.1 to create context-dependent attributes. For each of the above two types of characteristics, we fire the attributes for the word on the top of the stack and the two words on the front of the buffer. sections.heading: 7 Related Work
sections.text: We review the areas of related work. Lexicon generation. Natural language lexicons are often used by smaller seed lexicons that use different methods. Thelen and Riloff (2002) use patterns extracted from a large corpus to learn semantic lexicon from smaller seed lexicons, while our seed lexicon is evaluated by bootstrapping. Alfonseca et al. (2010) we use distribution similarities between different types of languages that contain semantic polarity labels for words and phrases created by random walks over a graph. Das and Smith (2012) learn potential semantic frames for unknown predictions by extending a lexicon framework. Sentiment lexicons contain semantic languages that contain semantic languages.

sections.heading: 8 Future Work
sections.text: In the current model, we first learn the weights under supervision (§ 3.1) and then propagate labels using these weights in a semi-supervised step with fixed property weights (§ 3.2). These can also be done together: perform an iteration of weight learning, propagate labels using these weights, perform a further iteration of weight learning using empirical labels such as gold labels, and learn and propagate further to convergence. This joint learning would be slower than the current approach, as the propagation of labels over the graph is an expensive step.Multi-label classification is an expensive one. We currently use the binary relevance method that trains a binary classifier for each attribute independently (Godbole and Sarawagi, 2004; Zhang and Zhou, 2005).

sections.heading: 9 Conclusion
sections.text: We have presented a graph-based semi-supervised method for constructing large annotated morphosyntactic lexicographs from small seed lexicographs. Our method is language independent and we have constructed lexicographs for 11 different languages. We have shown that the lexicographs constructed in this way help improve performance in morphological marking and dependency analysis when used as traits.

metadata.abstractText: Morpho-syntactic lexicons provide information about the morphological and syntactic roles of words in a language. Such lexicons are not available for all languages and even when available, their coverage can be limited. We present a graph-based semi-supervised learning method that uses the morphological, syntactic and semantic relations between words to automatically construct wide coverage lexicons from small seed sets. Our method is language-independent, and we show that we can expand a 1000 word seed lexicon to more than 100 times its size with high quality for 11 languages. In addition, the automatically created lexicons provide features that improve performance in two downstream tasks: morphological tagging and dependency parsing.
